title: Gary Edson
text:
Gary Edson is a former <a href="Americans">American</a> government official, entrepreneur, and former president of <a href="Conservation%20International">Conservation International</a>. He served previously as Chief Executive Officer of the <a href="Clinton%20Bush%20Haiti%20Fund">Clinton Bush Haiti Fund</a>, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization that concluded operations in late 2012.
From 2001 to 2004, Edson served in the administration of <a href="George%20W.%20Bush">George W. Bush</a> as <a href="Deputy%20National%20Security%20Advisor">Deputy National Security Advisor</a> and Deputy Assistant to the President for International Economic Affairs; he was also Deputy National Economic Advisor. In addition, he was the chief U.S. negotiator or “sherpa” for all presidential summits, including the <a href="G8">G8</a>, <a href="APEC">APEC</a>, US-EU, and the <a href="Summits%20of%20the%20Americas">Summits of the Americas</a>.
Edson co-led the development of the $45 billion <a href="President%27s%20Emergency%20Plan%20for%20AIDS%20Relief">President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief</a>, the largest commitment ever by any nation for an international health initiative. He is also credited with establishing the <a href="Millennium%20Challenge%20Corporation">Millennium Challenge Corporation</a> (MCC) to fight global poverty. The MCC uses increased aid to reward countries demonstrating a commitment to <a href="good%20governance">good governance</a>.
Edson left government in 2005 because of a serious illness, from which he has since recovered. He was a Managing Director at <a href="Stonebridge%20International">Stonebridge International</a>, and for a time sat on the <a href="Fulbright%20Scholarship">Fulbright Foreign Scholarship</a> Board.
One observer described Edson as “brainy” and “impatient… a spicy jalapeno pepper in the midst of the smooth cream cheese” of the White House. Former Secretary of State <a href="James%20Baker">James A. Baker</a> has called him “indispensable,” noting, "I've never known anybody from whom the taxpayers get a better deal." In her 2011 memoir, former Secretary of State <a href="Condoleezza%20Rice">Condoleezza Rice</a> praises Edson as being "one of the best 'policy engineers' I'd ever known, one of those rare individuals who can take an idea from inception to implementation."
Early career.
Earlier in his career, Edson served as Chief of Staff and General Counsel to U.S. Trade Representative <a href="Carla%20A.%20Hills">Carla A. Hills</a> from 1989 to 1992, and Special Assistant to Deputy Secretary of State <a href="Kenneth%20W.%20Dam">Kenneth W. Dam</a> from 1982 to 1985. He headed a <a href="private%20equity">private equity</a> firm, ECG, Inc., which acquired PAR Systems, Inc, a manufacturer of robotics systems, of which Edson was Chairman of the Board. 
Education.
Edson received a B.A. with honors in anthropology from <a href="Stanford%20University">Stanford University</a> in 1977, and J.D. and M.B.A. degrees from The <a href="University%20of%20Chicago">University of Chicago</a> in 1982. He was a <a href="Henry%20Luce%20Scholar">Henry Luce Scholar</a> in Japan, 1977-1978.
